Let me jump to some sellside.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

...... MoffattNathanson tends to get quoted a lot on this kind of stock, so we can start there.

BE11:16am

While we have never doubted the quality of the Netflix
product offering, we have recently had a hard time finding comfort in Netflix’s equity value. In early 2018, Netflix’s stock broke out above $200 per share, its valuation pushed above the $100 billion mark, and soon the company was more valuable (in equity terms) than Disney and Comcast, owners of hard assets and generators of free cash flow.
Since then, with each passing quarter of better-thanexpected subscriber growth but higher free cash flow losses, the stock kept rocketing. It wasn’t fun missing out
on this spectacular run, but we just couldn’t find a
methodology that showed upside to the stock price, even in our most aggressive models. To be clear, we think 10 to 15 year DCF models are interesting, but bullshit, and used by the sell-side to defend a stock that they want to champion.

red @hagilonone trick pony thus far
BE11:16am

Over the past few years, we have analyzed the company by valuing the U.S. business as a stand-alone “Blue Sky” asset and then seeing what the market was implying for the rest of the world operations. In June, we published our latest analysis, which used 88.4 million subscribers by year 2025, domestic RPU of $25, and EBITDA margins of 34%. Using a 12x 2025 EBITDA and an 8% discount rate, we estimated that the domestic present value was $66 billion, which means that the international assets would have been worth over $114 billion at the time.

Shinshin Number of people keenly awaiting the opportunity to subscribe to 8 competing streaming services at $9.99 a month: Zero. Number of people subbing to Netflix+1 and dusting off their pirate downloads for the rest: a lot.
11:16 am
BE11:17am

Of course, looking at this quarter’s results, that “Blue Sky” scenario looks downright psychedelic as 2Q 2019 U.S. subscriber adds turned negative on the back of $1 to $2 price hikes and an underwhelming content slate. This one quarter calls into question many of those 2025 endpoints.
Through the first three quarters of 2019 (assuming the 3Q guide is right), domestic net subscriber adds will be
running at 60% the rate of 2018, which will be the first
year of meaningful year-over-year deceleration. In other
words, the S-Curve in the U.S. may be finally be flattening after all these years of growth. As such, it will increase doubts about Netflix’s final resting subscriber base. Maybe it is 80 million vs. the 88.4 million
in our prior valuation case.

red look at disney this year. silent assasin. netflix not commercially viable lt. but sp is another matter
BE11:17am

Next, the acknowledgement that the price increase hurt subscriber growth in the quarter also brings into question Netflix’s ultimate pricing power.

CryptoWhipto ITV on the M&A radar again? Netflix or Liberty?
Geektrader By the end of the 3rd quarter Netflix will be back trading close to $4
BE11:19am

Netflix "moves from being a digital video store ... to a premium cable network on steroids", MW says.

AMALtd morning
Jon WDI ?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Lastly, as the company also acknowledged “we think Q2’s content slate drove less growth… than anticipated.” If so, what does this statement mean about both long-term content and marketing spending, especially as new competition begins to ramp in 4Q? Will Netflix always need to spend on original content and promotion to hold subscribers in the increasingly competitive U.S.? We think so. As such, if we assume that the 2025 end point is 80 million subs with $17
RPU and30% margin, this equates to a current equity value of $35 billion, which implies that the international value is $142 billion, or more than four times (!) the value of the U.S. business

BE11:21am

And the buyers are also out, I should note.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Netflix missed 2Q19 consensus revenue and subscriber estimates due
to pricing and content timing. We remain positive on the company’s global, multiyear
outlook given comments around the strength of scalable, globalized content
and improving profitability. We believe bulls remain focused on long-term subscriber
penetration regardless of quarterly bear-focused subscriber fluctuations. Our confidence
in Netflix fundamentals remains high, and company shares remain the most attractive
BUY idea in our coverage universe on a multi-year secular basis.

BE11:22am

That's Guggenheim.

BE11:22am

And this is Credit Suisse.

Tom Dalgleish Netflix only for insiders IMHO
11:22 am
BE11:23am

What we learned: (1) 3Q gross adds have rebounded and churn “materially”
improved per mgmt as price impacts fade (vast majority of price increases now
cycled through); (2) 3Q guide has net adds rebounding to up Y/Y (to 7.0m vs.
6.1m in 2Q18); (3) all other guidance was reaffirmed – margins, content spend,
FCF; (4) mgmt acknowledged how important content is to driving activations,
consistent with our view; (5) greater scale means bigger seasonal net add
beats/misses (a 1% impact was 800k 3 yrs ago, now 1.5m); (6) little assumed
in guide for new India mobile-only lower priced tier; (7) FCF is breakeven today
ex-studio build out; and (8) Game of Thrones did not influence the qtr.
■ Outlook: Some will say this miss suggests maturation or lack of pricing power;
we see neither. We would note Netflix misses have been followed by strong
qtrs, and, along those lines, we expect Netflix’s very strong 2H slate will lead to
a rebound in sub growth. Also, price increases of over 10% leading to a 1%
shortfall in subs does not suggest a lack of pricing power; in fact, just the
opposite. While this volatility is not for the faint of heart, we believe the 2Q19
miss will create a buying opportunity. 2019e EPS is $-0.16 to $3.12 due to a
non-cash Euro debt FX remeasurement, while revenue/EBIT are little changed.
■ Valuation: We lowered our DCF target $10 to $440 due to less subscriber
growth (2023e subs -1.7%) – CoE remains 11% and CoD 5%. Risks include
competition, content costs.

BE11:27am

. The obvious key strategic question for Netflix, which we don't cover, is how it will sustain subscriber growth when major content providers are pulling their content off Netflix to boost their own OTT services. One obvious route for Netflix is to go and acquire content via M&A and one candidate here should be ITV, with the UK being seen as a key content production market for global broadcasters.

BE11:29am

I mean, there are easier ways to buy production companies than buy a terrestrial broadcaster with Liberty in place as blocking shareholder then throw two thirds of the business away, but what do I know?

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Netflix’s main strategic issue is that it has been reliant on other parties to provide the bulk of its content and these providers such as AT&T and Disney are now pulling their programmes off the platform for use on their own platforms. Content is to a Pay-TV provider as oil is to a car and, if Netflix does not have sufficient content, then there is little reason for new subscribers to sign up.

At the same time, the policy of raising prices has had an obvious effect, even if Netflix states that the impact has been “slight”. Its main US rival Hulu is now 100% owned by Disney, which should give clearer strategic direction and Hulu has a clear advantage over Netflix in that the former is able to offer customers several options (ad-free, lower pricing with adverts etc) than Netflix. Hulu has also been reducing prices in the US vs Netflix which has been increasing them.

One obvious route for Netflix to take is to buy content to reduce the reliance on other providers. In this case, we see ITV as one obvious option, which has been a very substantial content arm and especially given the UK’s reputation amongst global broadcasters for producing high quality content.

A. M. showing my ignorance here, but what key content does ITV produce for the global market?
BE11:30am

As for the reverse angle, McCall was last asked about Liberty in March and said there was no indication of interest whatsoever that it wanted a bigger stake.

BE11:35am

And it's an agreed bid from PE-backed Stonegate, which might give the CMA some interesting casework.

BE11:35am

Bullet points via Liberum (again)

11:35 am
BE11:35am

TDR Capital backed Stonegate Pub Company has made an all-cash offer of 285p for Ei Group, equivalent to market cap of £1,273m.

285p has already been revised up from an original approach of 270p
This represents a 38.5% premium to yesterday’s closing price and 26.8% premium to recent high of 224.8p reached on 15 May 2019
This values the business at EV of £2,970m or 11.4x trailing EV/EBITDA, and 9.7x based on our FY19E estimates.
Last reported NAV was 331p with 350p forecast for FY19E although the announcement refers to the offer being at a 4.3% premium to the tangible NAV as at 31 March 2019
Stonegate believes its experience would effectively de-risk EI Group’s managed-house conversion strategy given its complementary brand formats, acquisition track record and national managed infrastructure.
The Ei Group Directors intend to unanimously recommend that shareholders vote in favour of the deal and have provided irrevocable undertakings for 0.58%.
We expect that the transaction will require CMA approval but current timetable is for acquisition to become effective 1Q 2020.

BE11:36am

Stonegate has agreed to make up 100 disposals to secure clearance in a preemptive move to keep the CMA happy.

BE11:37am

Dunno whether that'll be sufficient given the reasonable likelihood of exits resulting in closures rather than sales.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Back to Liberum:

BE11:37am

We are moving our target price to 285p to reflect the bid value. Our previous target price of 250p was based on 20% discount to last reported NAV of 331p. We believe the acquisition rationale is compelling and given the outlook for UK consumer and property valuation, could be attractive to Ei Group shareholders albeit this is still at a larger discount to forecast reported total NAV than some would like. However we note the commentary that the offer is at 4.3% premium to tangible asset value which excludes goodwill.

This, and the unlikelihood of a competing bid emerging, suggests limited scope for significant further upwards revision and we move to HOLD recommendation.

With forecasts for broadly flat PBT over the next three years, deleveraging and de-risking alongside annual asset revaluation and commercial property monetisation was seen as key catalysts for equity appreciation absent of a bid.

Stonegate has a strong track record for acquiring, integrating and converting pubs. We estimated the company has completed at least 15 acquisitions in the current decade, following TDR’s acquisition of 333 outlets from Mitchells & Butlers for £373m in August 2010.

This acquisition should enable Stonegate to at least triple its EBITDA. The combined estate should provide a substantial pool of pubs to either convert (from leased to managed) or sell. Thus, this could trigger a lot of follow-on corporate activity in the sector, particularly in tenanted and leased pubs in the short term.

BE11:47am

After a period of significant stock price volatility, the shares have now reached an attractive entry point, in our view. Although growth in the UK will continue to normalize, the potential for Fever-Tree's international expansion remains very attractive. Category fundamentals continue to be very supportive, with the premiumisation of spirits and the global trend towards mixed drinks representing a big opportunity for the company to continue its growth trajectory. While competition should continue to intensify as a result of the category's attractiveness and low barriers to entry, Fever-Tree is in a strong position, last but not least because it has built strong relationships with some of the world's largest spirits companies, which we see as an important competitive advantage. Why buy now? Following two months of weak UK Nielsen numbers, we are reasonably confident that 1H19 results, on July 23rd, should reassure and, therefore, believe that now is good time to buy the shares.

The key message from EVE’s pre-close H1 FY19 trading update is that financial performance is on track. As importantly, EVE has delivered operationally and strategically on its commitment given at the FY18 results in March, viz “focus for the next 6 to 12 months is to continue to lay the foundations for the rebuild strategy, embed the changes into the business and to focus on reducing underlying EBITDA losses, whilst growing revenue in a sustainable way.” So far so good, we think, on the decisive actions taken, whilst fully recognising that EVE’s transformation in its true sense – the restoration of vitality, growth and competitiveness – will likely be a considered and protracted process, alongside the delivery of profitable growth in the medium term.

BE12:00pm

Trading is at rebased levels -- ie, bad but no worse than expected -- but confidence in management to straighten things out should really be nil now.

BE12:01pm

ASOS has issued an unscheduled (but not entirely unexpected) profit warning this morning (it was due to report a trading update next week).- Sales for the 4 months to 30 June have come in at +11% on a constant currency basis. We hadn't seen any consensus data, but suspect that the consensus expectation was more like 18% (the company delivered 11% growth in FY H1 and guided at its Interims that it expected full-year sales growth of 15%, implying that it was expecting sales growth in H2 to improve, which has not happened). Sales performance in the UK remains robust (+16%), but is very weak in both Europe (+3%) and the US (+6%), with the company blaming warehousing issues. The company is now guiding that it expects sales growth for the full year to be around 11%, versus 15% previously.- Pre Tax Profits are now guided to be £30-35m for the year, implying an EBIT margin of c1.2%. Previous guidance had been for EBIT margins to be c2% and, according to Bloomberg, consensus was forecasting Pre Tax Profits of around £56m, so this is a downgrade of around 40%, albeit that is largely due to the 'law of small numbers'.- The profit downgrade appears to more than feed through into the cash flow statement; the company is now guiding to year-end net debt of £100m, versus £50m previously. Any near-term concerns about financing, however, are likely to be allayed by the fact that the company has secured a new, 5-year, £350m revolving credit facility.- All in all, this is a poor statement. However, Markit data suggests that ASOS had become one of the most shorted stocks in Europe, so there will have been a lot of investors anticipating something like this, making it difficult to predict how the shares will react today.

The retail sector is defined by customer relevance amidst changing shopping habits. ASOS has been at the forefront of that revolution, disrupting the status quo and setting the standards for others to follow. Today’s profit warning is the latest in a number of self-inflicted execution failings, a point that won’t be lost on management. Assuming the warehouse problems can be resolved ahead of peak, then the combination of weak valuation and a relevant, high growth, global consumer proposition will make this an excellent buying opportunity. For now, we downgrade to Hold and look for clarity that ASOS can sharpen up execution ahead of peak.
